results.title: SIemens, Mitsubishi in talks on Alstom - report
results.content:
Another twist in the battle for Alstom's prized energy business, just days before Siemens was expected to table a formal offer to outflank US giant General Electric.

Bloomberg News has reported that the German engineering group is in talks with Tokyo-based Mitsubishi Heavy about a joint offer for the French group's energy assets, in an attempt to ward off GE's $17bn approach.

Siemens has already said that it expects to put forward a formal proposal for the business by June 16, in a heavily politicised skirmish that has already seen GE chief executive Jeff Immelt and Siemens' French chairman Christophe de Maistre hauled before French lawmakers to tout the respective merits of a potential deal.

Bloomberg reported on Wednesday that one option now being discussed is for Mitsubishi Heavy to buy Alstom's steam and grid business and Siemens to get the French company's gas turbine operations, citing people familiar with the talks.

We should note that the story hasn't been confirmed.

At pixel time, Siemens shares were trading about 1.4 per cent lower at €98.47 as investors digest the latest moves.
results.abstract: Another twist in the battle for Alstom's prized energy business, just days before Siemens was expected to table a formal offer to outflank US giant General Electric.

results.title: Portuguese bonds supported by successful auction
results.content:
Portugal's bond market has been buoyed by Lisbon's first auction of long term debt since exiting a punishing three-year bailout in May, with benchmark borrowing costs at the lowest since 2005, reports Peter Wise in Lisbon.

The IGCP, the public debt agency, said it issued €975m in 10-year government bonds, above the initially targeted amount of €500m-€750m, at a yield of 3.25 per cent. This compares with a yield of 3.57% in the previous auction of 10-year debt in April. Demand exceeded the amount issued by 2.43 times.

Despite tapping the market for more than expected, the successful auction helped keep the Portuguese bond market steady on Wednesday.

Tiago da Costa Cardoso, an analyst at XTB Portugal, said the recent announcement by the European Central Bank that it was prepared to take radical measures to support lending had increased investors' appetite for risk.

João Queiroz, head of trading at GoBulling said:

Investors are willing to invest in Portuguese debt despite doubts over whether the country has the capacity to generate the primary deficit surpluses that will be required to repay those debts.

The auction marked a successful return to capital markets for Portugal after the country's €78bn bailout by the EU, the ECB and the International Monetary Fund formally ended on May 17.

The debt issued on Wednesday will go towards a "cash cushion" for 2015, given that Lisbon has already raised sufficient funds to cover its borrowing requirements for 2014.
results.abstract: Portugal's bond market has been buoyed by Lisbon's first auction of long term debt since exiting a punishing three-year bailout in May, with benchmark borrowing costs at the lowest since 2005, reports Peter Wise in Lisbon.

results.title: US mortgage applications bounce back
results.content:
The US mortgage market has rebounded sharply after two weeks of declines.

Applications climbed 10.3 per cent last week, according to an index from the Mortgage Bankers' Association, snapping two weeks of declines.

Demand rose for loans to refinance existing mortgages - up 11 per cent, from a week earlier; applications for loans for new purchases climbed 9 per cent.

Although US house prices have continued to rise since reaching a bottom in 2011, a stalling in activity in sales over the last 12 months has become an increasing concern for the Federal Reserve.

American homebuyers now face higher prices, loftier mortgage rates and tighter lending rules.
results.abstract: The US mortgage market has rebounded sharply after two weeks of declines.

results.title: Ireland 'confident' on EU tax probe
results.content:
The Irish government said it was "confident" that it did not breach EU rules on state aid in relation to taxing global companies, but admitted that its tax authorities "in certain limited circumstances" offered advice to companies on how to apply the relevant tax laws.

In a statement after the European Commission announced that it had opened formal investigations into tax arrangements between three EU member states and Apple, Starbucks and a division of Fiat, the finance ministry said:

Ireland is confident that there is no state aid rule breach in this case and we will defend all aspects vigorously.

The ministry said Ireland did not have a statutorily based tax ruling system, adding:

Like other tax administrations in other countries, the Revenue Commissioners, in certain limited circumstances, operate a system of non-binding advance opinions where companies can seek advice on the correct application of the law in their self-assessment tax filings.

It said the ministry's technical experts did not believe there was any state aid involved in its arrangements with "a particular company" - a reference to Apple, which uses Ireland extensively in its global tax planning.

We will now turn to providing our detailed, technical legal rebuttal to the Commission's position and if necessary will defend our position in the European courts.
results.abstract: The Irish government said it was "confident" that it did not breach EU rules on state aid in relation to taxing global companies, but admitted that its tax authorities "in certain limited circumstances" offered advice to companies on how to apply the relevant tax laws.

results.title: Green REIT's shares edge higher on acquisition
results.content:
Listed property investment group Green REIT said on Wednesday it planned to acquire a large commercial property portfolio in Dublin for €375m euros.

The Dublin-focused group said the acquisition, which included office and retail space, was in line with its objective "to assemble a portfolio of prime and good quality secondary properties with a Dublin focus".

The portfolio's total space is 650,000 square feet and has an occupancy rate of 97 per cent with an initial yield of 6 per cent.

It includes office buildings at Georges Quay and George's Court and retail and other commercial space in Westend Retail Park in Blanchardstown.

Pioneer Investments, Invesco, Northern Trust, GAM Fund Management and RBC Dexia are among the office tenants, while the retail mix includes Next, Nike, Gap, Heatons, New Look, Lidl and Argos

Shares in the company, which has a market capitalisation of €887.1m were trading about 1.14 per cent higher at €1.33 by 11am.

The acquisition was conditional upon the sellers fulfilling certain conditions.

Green Reit would fund the acquisition with cash. It said it intended to raise bank debt against the properties in due course.
results.abstract: Listed property investment group Green REIT said on Wednesday it planned to acquire a large commercial property portfolio in Dublin for €375m euros.

results.title: Fast New York Open: Gazing at the housing market
results.content:
The desert that is the US economic calendar will offer little for investors to pick through on Wednesday.

Instead, they will be left waiting for mortgage data early this morning and the latest tally on the budget balance from the US Treasury.

The mortgage figures have offered a rather morose view of the housing market, steadily shifting lower in May despite rising pending home sales. Of the data, economists with Pantheon Macroeconomics said:

After four straight declines we hope to see at least a modest rebound in the purchase applications index, which stood at just 171.6.

Meanwhile, the monthly budget statement is expected to fall back into deficit territory after a surge in tax collections in April.

The corporate diary is equally light, with quarterly results from H&R Block and Restoration Hardware.

Investors will also be listening to presentations at the Morgan Stanley US Financials Conference, with executives from JPMorgan, American Express and Ally Financial set to speak.

S&P 500 futures suggest the most widely tracked equity index will open down 6 points in New York after falling marginally a day earlier.

US Treasuries were flat in European trading, with the yield on the ten-year note at 2.65 per cent.
results.abstract: The desert that is the US economic calendar will offer little for investors to pick through on Wednesday.

results.title: Lululemon founder to vote against directors
results.content:
Here's a lulu of a board row at lululemon - the fitness apparel company that suffered a product recall for some "see-through" yoga pants last year.

The company's outspoken founder and 27-per-cent shareholder Chip Wilson has announced that he is voting against the re-election of the board chairman Michael Casey and director RoAnn Costin today.

Mr Wilson, who is also a director of the company, said in a statement that he was excited by the new management team - a new CEO and head of product quality - he had helped put in place after returning from Australia last year to aid in the recovery from the product recall. But, he was "concerned that the Board is not aligned with the core values of product and innovation on which lululemon was founded and on which the company thrived. As a 27 per cent shareholder in the company, I believe change is now needed at the Board level to increase shareholder value."

Here are his key reasons:

I was hopeful that we would be able to create a balance at lululemon between product and growth that would complement each other. Instead, I have found a palpable imbalance in Board representation, which is heavily weighted towards short-term results at the expense of product, culture and brand and longer-term corporate goals. I believe this is impacting the company's prospects. My vote today sends a signal to the financial community that the company must address this imbalance if lululemon is to fully recover.

Mr Wilson founded the company in Vancouver in 1998, but Mr Casey, a former Starbucks executive, had taken over as chairman after Mr Wilson resigned "to focus on other ventures".

Last November, he had told Bloomberg TV that complaints over "see-through pants" were due to overweight women. Some women's bodies "just don't actually work" for Lululemon trousers, he said.

RoAnn Costin is president of a private Boston-based equity company that focuses on investing in early and expansion-stage consumer product and retailing companies.

The annual meeting is at noon Pacific time today in Vancouver.
results.abstract: Here's a lulu of a board row at lululemon - the fitness apparel company that suffered a product recall for some "see-through" yoga pants last year.

results.title: EU opens tax deals probe into Apple, Starbucks
results.content:
Brussels has opened a formal probe into tax deals that countries including Ireland and the Netherlands have used to attract companies such as Apple and Starbucks, marking a significant escalation in a global crackdown on corporate tax strategies.

The announcement from the EU, heavily trailed on Tuesday, will centre on so-called transfer pricing arrangements large corporates use to make commercial transactions between their own units, frequently taking advantage of less onerous tax regimes between countries.

The European Commission said it has opened three "in-depth" investigations to examine whether decisions by tax authorities in Ireland, the Netherlands and Luxembourg on tax owed by Apple, Starbucks and Fiat Finance and Trade have complied with EU rules on state aid.

Said EU competition chief Joaquín Almunia:

In the current context of tight public budgets, it is particularly important that large multinationals pay their fair share of taxes.

Under the EU's state aid rules, national authorities cannot take measures allowing certain companies to pay less tax than they should if the tax rules of the Member State were applied in a fair and non-discriminatory way.

The Commission said it would examine whether three transfer pricing arrangements in particular were in breach of state aid rules:

  • the individual rulings issued by the Irish tax authorities on the calculation of the taxable profit allocated to the Irish branches of Apple Sales International and of Apple Operations Europe;

  • the individual ruling issued by the Dutch tax authorities on the calculation of the taxable basis in the Netherlands for manufacturing activities of Starbucks Manufacturing EMEA BV;

  • the individual ruling issued by the Luxembourgish tax authorities on the calculation of the taxable basis in Luxembourg for the financing activities of Fiat Finance and Trade.
results.abstract: Brussels has opened a formal probe into tax deals that countries including Ireland and the Netherlands have used to attract companies such as Apple and Starbucks, marking a significant escalation in a global crackdown on corporate tax strategies.

results.title: Spanish regions need to find €87bn - Moody's
results.content:
Spain's indebted regions should be able to regain access to bond markets over the next few years as long as economic growth and fiscal consolidation does not disappoint, Moody's predicted in a report.

Just as well, as they need to raise a whopping €87bn over the next three years - a big ask possibly for a central government that is currently propping up quite a few of them.

The Spanish government has supported the fairly autonomous regions through a facility called Fondo de Liquidez Autonomico, or FLA. Regions will have to start repaying the loans this autumn, but Moody's predicts that many of the more stricken regions will have to continue to rely on a combination of the FLA, bank loans and bond sales.

A return to pre-financial-crisis market access for regions is possible, but we expect that regions are likely to borrow from both government facilities and the market/ banks. Even with further consolidation, some fiscally weaker regions will still require favourable borrowing conditions under a government funding scheme.

However, as regions rebalance their budgets, we believe that the government is likely to launch a "reformed" FLA that carries no fiscal/debt conditionality, and which would thereby become an option for all regions.

Some of the stronger regions, like the Basque country and Madrid, already enjoy easy access to markets, but overall the Spanish sub-sovereigns have financing requirements of €34bn this year, €29bn in 2015 and €24bn in 2016, the rating agency estimates.

The breakdown can be seen in the chart below.
results.abstract: Spain's indebted regions should be able to regain access to bond markets over the next few years as long as economic growth and fiscal consolidation does not disappoint, Moody's predicted in a report.

results.title: Iraq to up oil production despite Mosul - minister
results.content:
Iraq's oil minister has struck a defiant note - saying the country will raise production to 4m barrels of oil per day before the end of the year, in spite of the deteriorating security situation in the north of the country, reports Neil Hume from Opec's meeting in Vienna.

On Tuesday, the government in Baghdad asked parliament to declare a state of emergency after extremists took control of the northern city of Mosul.

Concern is growing that escalating unrest in the oil-rich region could threaten exports from Iraq, the second biggest Opec producer.

However, Oil minister, Abdul Kareem Luaibi sought to play down fears, telling reporters ahead of the Opec conference in Vienna that Iraq's main export facilities in the south of the country were "very, very safe.

"All of our activities, production and exports now are in the south," he said, adding that shipments were currently running at around 2.6m barrels per day."The south is very very safe, the accident is only in the north," he said.

Iraq's daily production had fallen by around 8 percent since reaching a 35-year high of 3.6m barrels in February, due to political disputes and the bombing of infrastructure.

Iraq's northern export pipeline, which can carry some 600,000 barrels a day of crude from Kirkuk to the Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan, has been out of action since early March.

Mr Luaibi again flagged the possibility of using some eight oil product pipelines to transfer crude from the north for domestic use, freeing up other supplies for export.

Opec, which produces more than a third of the world's oil, is widely expected to roll over its 30m b/d production target at the conclusion of Wednesday's meeting.

Saudi Arabian oil minister Ali al-Naimi, also speaking at the conference in Vienna, said he expected Opec to leave its production ceiling unchanged.

"Everything is in good order, supply is good, demand is good, the price is good," al- Naimi told reporters. "$100, $110, $95 is a good price."
results.abstract: Iraq's oil minister has struck a defiant note - saying the country will raise production to 4m barrels of oil per day before the end of the year, in spite of the deteriorating security situation in the north of the country, reports Neil Hume from Opec's meeting in Vienna.
